title: The Concert Dilemma: Maximizing Economic Surplus
original_question: Sarah won a non-transferable ticket to a jazz concert that she values at 80. Alternatively, she could work a shift at a local cafe and earn 50. A third option is attending a friend's birthday dinner, which she values at 60 but costs 20 to attend. While Sarah is deciding, her brother offers her 10 to help him move furniture for an hour, a task she dislikes so much she would pay 15 to avoid it. If Sarah chooses to go to the jazz concert, what is her total economic surplus from this decision?

segments.text: Sarah won a non-transferable ticket to a jazz concert that she values at 80.
segments.explanation: This represents the total benefit or WTP Sarah has for the concert experience.

segments.text: Alternatively, she could work a shift at a local cafe and earn 50.
segments.explanation: Potential earnings from working are a candidate for the opportunity cost of her time.

segments.text: A third option is attending a friend's birthday dinner, which she values at 60 but costs 20 to attend.
segments.explanation: The value of this alternative is its net benefit: 60 - 20 = 40.

segments.text: Her brother offers her 10 to help him move furniture for an hour, a task she dislikes so much she would pay 15 to avoid it.
segments.highlight_text: offers her 10 to help him move furniture for an hour, a task she dislikes so much she would pay 15 to avoid it
segments.explanation: The cost (dislike of 15) exceeds the benefit (10), making this a negative surplus activity that would never be the 'next best' choice.

segments.text: If Sarah chooses to go to the jazz concert, what is her total economic surplus from this decision?
segments.knowledge: Economic Surplus = Total Benefits - Total Costs
segments.explanation: The goal is to calculate the surplus of the chosen action relative to its opportunity cost.

traps.title: Misidentifying Opportunity Cost
traps.description: Students often sum all alternative values (50 + 40) instead of only taking the single next-best alternative.

traps.title: Irrelevant Negative Surplus Options
traps.description: The furniture moving option offers a benefit of 10 but a cost of 15, resulting in a -5 surplus. It should be ignored in the opportunity cost calculation.

solution.step_desc: Identify the benefit of the chosen action.
solution.content: Sarah's total benefit (WTP) for the concert is 80.

solution.step_desc: Determine the Opportunity Cost by evaluating alternatives.
solution.content: Option A: Work (Surplus = 50). Option B: Dinner (60 - 20 = 40). Option C: Moving (-5). The 'Next Best Alternative' is the work shift, valued at 50.

solution.source_label: Economic Surplus = Total Benefits - Total Costs

title: The Bakery's Expansion: Rational Decision Making
original_question: A bakery owner is deciding how many extra bakers to hire for the morning shift. The first baker adds 100 in daily revenue and costs 60 in wages. The second baker adds 80 in revenue and costs 60. The third baker adds 65 in revenue but requires an additional oven lease of 10 per day plus the 60 wage. The fourth baker adds 55 in revenue and costs 60. The owner already spent 500 on a marketing campaign last month that cannot be refunded. According to the Rational Rule, how many extra bakers should be hired?

segments.text: The first baker adds 100 in daily revenue and costs 60 in wages.
segments.explanation: MB (100) > MC (60), so hiring the first baker is rational.

segments.text: The second baker adds 80 in revenue and costs 60.
segments.explanation: MB (80) > MC (60), so hiring the second baker increases total surplus.

segments.text: The third baker adds 65 in revenue but requires an additional oven lease of 10 per day plus the 60 wage.
segments.highlight_text: 65 in revenue but requires an additional oven lease of 10 per day plus the 60 wage
segments.explanation: The MC for the 3rd baker is the wage (60) plus the equipment cost (10), totaling 70.

segments.text: The owner already spent 500 on a marketing campaign last month that cannot be refunded.
segments.highlight_text: 500 on a marketing campaign last month that cannot be refunded
segments.explanation: This 500 is a sunk cost and should be ignored in current decision-making.

segments.text: According to the Rational Rule, how many extra bakers should be hired?
segments.highlight_text: how many extra bakers should be hired
segments.explanation: Apply the rule 'Keep doing it as long as MB is greater than or equal to MC'.

traps.title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
traps.description: Students might try to subtract the 500 marketing cost from the marginal benefits, which is incorrect as the money is already gone.

traps.title: Ignoring Hidden Marginal Costs
traps.description: The third baker's cost isn't just the wage; it includes the 10 oven lease, making the total MC 70, which exceeds the MB of 65.

solution.step_desc: Analyze the first and second bakers using the Rational Rule.
solution.content: Baker 1: MB=100, MC=60 (Hire). Baker 2: MB=80, MC=60 (Hire).

solution.step_desc: Analyze the third baker's marginal impact.
solution.content: Baker 3: MB=65. MC = Wage (60) + Oven (10) = 70. Since MB (65) < MC (70), do not hire.
Ignore the 500 sunk cost. The owner should hire 2 bakers to maximize economic surplus.
